case_name: Associated Hotels of India Ltd. and Mohan Singh Oberoi v. Jodha Mal Kuthiala

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 320/58 filed in Supreme Court of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 320/58. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd January, 1957,

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 22nd January 1957 of Punjab High Court in Civil Misc. No. 24/C of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd January, 1957, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Misc. No. 24/C of 1955. N. Pritt, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji and P.L. Vohra, for the Appellants.

facts.text: Appellants are Associated Hotels of India Ltd. and its Managing Director Mohan Singh Oberoi.

anchor.surface_text: The Associated Hotels of India Ltd., and its Managing Director Mohan Singh Oberoi  hereafter called appellants 1 and 2 respectively  had filed an application in the High Court of Punjab under O. 45, r. 15

facts.text: Agreement dated October 2, 1947 between respondent and appellants for sale of Nedous Hotel at Lahore for Rs. 52,75,000.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that by an agreement dated October 2, 1947, the respondent had agreed to sell to the appellants certain property known as Nedous Hotel at Lahore for Rs. 52,75,000. In pursuance of the terms of the said agreement the appellants had paid the respondent Rs. 5,00,000

facts.text: Appellants paid Rs. 5,00,000 as earnest money to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the terms of the said agreement the appellants had paid the respondent Rs. 5,00,000 by, way of earnest money. It, however, turned out that the respondents title to the property in question was defective,

facts.text: Respondent's title to Nedous Hotel was defective, sale could not be completed.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, turned out that the respondents title to the property in question was defective, and so the sale companyld number be companypleted. That is why the appellants had to file a suit in the companyrt of the Senior Subordinate Judge at Lahore

facts.text: Appellants filed suit in Senior Subordinate Judge at Lahore for Rs. 5,10,000 (earnest + interest).

anchor.surface_text: claiming to recover from the respondent a sum of Rs. 5,10,000 this amount included Rs. 5,00,000 paid by the appellants to the respondent as earnest money and interest accrued due thereon up to the date of the suit.

facts.text: Trial court (Senior Subordinate Judge Lahore) decreed Rs. 5,08,333-5-4 + future interest 5% p.a. in favour of appellant 2.

anchor.surface_text: In the said suit the trial judge passed a decree for Rs. 5,08,333-5-4 with future interest thereon at 5 per annum in favour of appellant 2. The claim made by appellant I was rejected.

facts.text: Lahore High Court allowed respondent's appeal, set aside trial decree, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was challenged by the respondent before the Lahore High Court. The High Court upheld the companytentions raised by the respondent, allowed his appeal, set aside the decree passed in favour of appellant 2 and dismissed the appellants suit with companyts.

facts.text: Federal Court of Pakistan allowed appellants' appeal, restored trial court decree on December 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: This decree led to an appeal by the appellants before the Federal Court of Pakistan. The Federal Court in turn allowed the appeal in favour of appellant 2 and restored the decree passed in his favour by the trial companyrt. This decree was passed on December 21, 1953.

facts.text: Appellants applied in Punjab High Court under O.45 r.15 CPC for execution of Federal Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The present application made by the appellants in the Punjab High Court under O. 45, r. 15 is intended to obtain the execution of this decree.

facts.text: After trial decree, before Lahore HC decision, appellants executed decree; respondent applied for stay.

anchor.surface_text: After the trial companyrt had passed its decree and before the date of the decision of the Lahore High Court, the appellants had put the decree in execution and thereupon the respondent had applied for stay of the said execution before the Lahore High Court.

facts.text: Lahore HC stayed execution on condition respondent deposit Rs. 3,00,000 and furnish security for balance.

anchor.surface_text: On the said application the Lahore High Court ordered that the execution taken out by the appellants should be stayed on companydition that the respondent should deposit a sum of Rs. 3,00,000 in the High Court and furnish security for the balance of the decretal amount.

facts.text: Respondent deposited Rs. 3,00,000 and furnished security.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this order the respondent deposited the amount and furnished the security.

facts.text: After Lahore HC allowed appeal, respondent applied for refund of deposit on December 16, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently when the Lahore High Court allowed the respondents appeal he applied for a refund of the amount already deposited by him, and his application was allowed on December 16, 1949.

facts.text: Lahore HC directed notice to Custodian on December 16, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, however, the Lahore High Court directed that information of its order allowing the respondent to withdraw the amount should be given to the Custodian.

facts.text: Custodian moved for review on December 20, 1949, claiming deposit as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian then moved the High Court on December 20, 1949, for a review of its order on the ground that the amount in question was evacuee property and as such it vested in him.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed appellants' execution application on January 22, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1957, the High Court of Punjab dismissed the petition holding that...

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Suit filed by appellants on May 8, 1947 in Lahore court (from dissent).

anchor.surface_text: On May 8, 1947, the appellants filed a suit in the companyrt of the Senior Subordinate Judge at Lahore against the respondent for the recovery of Rs. 5,10,000,

facts.text: Trial court decreed on March 14, 1949 (dissent).

anchor.surface_text: This suit was decreed by the Senior Subordinate Judge on March 14,1949, for a sum of Rs. 5,08,333/5/4 with future interest 5 per annum

facts.text: Lahore HC reversed on November 24, 1949 (dissent).

anchor.surface_text: on November 24, 1949, the decree of the trial companyrt was reversed and the suit dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Stay order by Lahore HC on April 27, 1949 requiring Rs. 3L deposit.

anchor.surface_text: on April 27, 1949, obtained from the High Court an order of stay of the execution on the companydition that he deposited a sum of Rs. 3 lacs

issues.text: whether the decree under execution attracts the provisions of s. 4(3) of the Order

anchor.surface_text: On these contentions the question which logically must first be considered is whether the decree under execution attracts the provisions of s. 4 3  of the Order.

anchor.surface_text: The question which we have to consider is whether the proceedings from which the appeal to the Federal Court arose fall within s. 4 1  if they do s. 4 3  will come into operation.

arguments.claim: Effect in s.4(3) wider than execute, includes recognition without suit.

anchor.surface_text: The word effect is wider than the words enforce or execute. There are decrees which are not executed in the ordinary sense of the term but are given effect to e. g., decrees for dissolution of marriage

holdings.text: s. 4(1) does not apply to all proceedings pending at the material time before the specified courts but only such of them in respect of which the jurisdiction of the trial court would have been affected by the passing of the Act or by the transfer of certain territories.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we feel no difficulty in holding that s. 4 1  does not apply to all proceedings pending at the material time before the specified courts but only such of them in respect of which the jurisdiction of the trial court would have been affected by the passing of the Act or by the transfer of certain territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and harmonious construction of s.4 considering preamble, object to avoid jurisdictional difficulties from partition, and redundancy argument if applied broadly.

holdings.text: The proceedings from which the appeal to the Federal Court arose do not fall within s. 4(1).

anchor.surface_text: On these contentions the question which logically must first be considered is whether the decree under execution attracts the provisions of s. 4 3  of the Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction of Lahore court unaffected as cause of action entirely at Lahore, no territory transfer impact.

holdings.text: The present suit does not fall within s. 4(1) at all.

anchor.surface_text: The next question which must be considered is whether the present suit falls within s. 4 1  at all. The answer to this question must obviously be in the negative.The material allegations made by the appellants in the plaint filed by them in the present suit clearly show that the whole cause of action had accrued within the jurisdiction of the Senior Sub-Judge at Lahore.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cause of action accrued wholly in Lahore jurisdiction under s.20(c) CPC, unaffected by partition.

holdings.text: Clause (2) of s.4 applies to an appeal before the Federal Court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 2  deals with appeals or revisional applications arising from the pending proceedings covered by cl. 1 . The learned Solicitor-General contends that this clause cannot apply to an appeal before the Federal Court... In our opinion there is no doubt that the word appeal in the context must mean any appeal or appeals allowed by law in respect of pending proceedings covered by cl. 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Word 'appeal' means any appeal allowed by law; narrow reading leads to anomalous consequences.

holdings.text: 'Effect shall be given to' in s.4(3) means the decree shall be executed as if passed by a court of competent jurisdiction within the Dominion where execution is sought.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to s. 4 3 . The Solicitor-General contends that the expression,, effect shall be given to in this clause does not mean that the decree shall be executed... the expression,, effect shall be given to ... must inevitably mean that the decree ... should be executed in India on the basis that the judgment has been competently pronounced by an Indian court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory fiction requires direct execution, departing from private international law; applies to criminal sentences too; excludes only s.13(a) plea if suit, but provides execution.

holdings.text: The decree under execution does not attract the provisions of s.4(3) of the Order.

anchor.surface_text: On these contentions the question which logically must first be considered is whether the decree under execution attracts the provisions of s. 4 3  of the Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Does not fall under s.4(1), so s.4(3) inapplicable.

holdings.text: The application under O.45 r.15 CPC is incompetent; appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, though we have differed from the conclusion of the High Court in regard to the applicability of s. 4 of the Order that does not affect the final result of the appeal because on the view we take about the scope and effect of the provisions of s. 4 we hold that the application made by the appellants before the High Court under O. 45, r. 15 was incompetent, and so the High Court was right in dismissing it. The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 inapplicable; High Court correctly dismissed despite error on s.4 applicability.

holdings.text: The Indian Independence (Legal Proceedings) Order, 1947 remains in force.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1957, the High Court of Punjab dismissed the petition holding that in spite of the coming into force of the Indian Constitution the Order was still in force

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not disputed; High Court finding accepted implicitly.

precedents.case_name: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote
precedents.cited_proposition: Jurisdiction in personal actions lies in courts of country where defendant resides; actor sequitur forum rei; territorial jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: The general rule is that the plaintiff must sue in the court to which the defendant is subject at the time of suit

The doctrine of harmonious construction, construed to avoid post-partition jurisdictional difficulties, grounds the holding limiting s. 4(1) to proceedings where trial court jurisdiction would be affected.

The doctrine of harmonious construction addresses the issue of whether s. 4(1) applies to all pending proceedings or only those affecting jurisdiction, by focusing on post-partition jurisdictional object.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we feel no difficulty in holding that s. 4 1  does not apply to all proceedings pending at the material time before the specified courts but only such of them in respect of which the jurisdiction of the trial court would have been affected by the passing of the Act or by the transfer of certain territories.
The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The next question which must be considered is whether the present suit falls within s. 4 1  at all. The answer to this question must obviously be in the negative.The material allegations made by the appellants in the plaint filed by them in the present suit clearly show that the whole cause of action had accrued within the jurisdiction of the Senior Sub-Judge at Lahore.
The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed with costs.
he companyrt held that s. 4 1  applied to the proceedings and that we think was clearly right. It was a proceeding validly instituted before the Alipo

edges.explanation: Holding affirms clause (2) of s.4 applies to FC appeal, resolving issue

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 2  deals with appeals or revisional applications arising from the pending proceedings covered by cl. 1 . The learned Solicitor-General contends that this clause cannot apply to an appeal before the Federal Court... In our opinion there is no doubt that the word appeal in the context must mean any appeal or appeals allowed by law in respect of pending proceedings covered by cl. 1 .
The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to s. 4 3 . The Solicitor-General contends that the expression,, effect shall be given to in this clause does not mean that the decree shall be executed... the expression,, effect shall be given to ... must inevitably mean that the decree ... should be executed in India on the basis that the judgment has been competently pronounced by an Indian court.
The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed with costs.
